thread.title: India achieves major aviation development

author: eTN Editor
title: India achieves major aviation development
text:
India achieves major aviation development Adv: 
By Anil Mathur, eTN India Correspondent | Jul 13, 2015 Adv: 
INDIA (eTN) - India achieved a major revolutionary step today, July 13, 2015, in the navigational field when Civil Aviation Minister Ashok Gajapathi Raju formally launched the GAGAN - GPS Aided Geo Augmented Navigation system. This system is set to play a significant role in improving not only air navigation but will also aid other development activities, whether it be road transport, fishing, weather research, or defense. 
The GAGAN is set to change the aviation scene, and it has been 15 years in the making, with the Airports Authority of India and the Indian Space Research Organization collaborating on the massive project. 
The GAGAN cost Rs 774 crores, along with a government grant of Rs 378 crores, and AAI investment of Rs 226 crores, and ISRO support in the amount of Rs 170 crores. 
Dependency on ground-based infrastructure will be reduced with the launch of GAGAN, emphasized the scientists and AAI officials at the launch, who said that in the days to come, more use can be made of the project, which is one of the few such ones in the world. 
GAGAN in Hindi means the sky, and the leadership was thrilled that this is a sign of success which has sent Indian aviation beyond the skies.
